title: Grain Storage | Grain Bags and Bunkers

tasks.task: Identify tasks and subtasks related to farming, agriculture, and operating farming equipment as depicted in the transcript.
subtasks: Welcome attendees and introduce oneself as the consultant managing the GRDC's grain storage extension project.
Briefly explain the topic on "best results for bags and bunkers" in grain storage.
Address housekeeping items, including Q&A window availability and contact information for technical support.
Discuss the role of grain bags and bunkers in the overall grain storage system, considering capital costs and labor requirements.
Emphasize the importance of central site selection for bags and proper site preparation (height, drainage, compacted surface, lack of obstructions).
Explain the thumb test for quality bag selection and the significance of proper sealing techniques (square ends, correct stretch, preventing overfilling).
Highlight the importance of patching and monitoring bags regularly to prevent moisture and pest entry.
Mention strategies for managing grain spills, pest control (baiting, fencing), and outloading methods.
Discuss the pros and cons of grain bags and bunkers, including low capital costs, flexible location, but higher labor requirements and limited aeration capabilities.
Propose methods for securing and maintaining bunker structures, such as slope drainage, grading, and using concrete or earth walls.
Compare pest prevention, control, and monitoring methods applicable to bags and bunkers versus permanent storage solutions.
Address common concerns about fumigation and phosphine treatment in bags, emphasizing the need for proper seals and fan-assisted venting.
Provide resources for further information and encourage questions via Q&A window.
